qas.question: What was in James Garfield that they wanted to get out?
What did Bell think was wrong with the bed, which prevented his machine from finding the bullet?
On which run did Bell's metal detector give a small indication?
When did Bell's metal detector work well?

context: Bell is also credited with developing one of the early versions of a <a0_0>metal detector<a0_0/> in 1881. The device was quickly put together in an attempt to find the <a1_0>bullet<a1_0/> in the body of U.S. President James Garfield. According to some accounts, the metal detector worked flawlessly <a4_0>in tests<a4_0/> but did not find the assassin's bullet partly because the <a2_0>metal bed frame<a2_0/> on which the President was lying disturbed the instrument, resulting in static. The president's surgeons, who were skeptical of the device, ignored Bell's requests to move the president to a bed not fitted with metal springs. Alternatively, although Bell had detected a slight sound on his <a3_0>first<a3_0/> test, the bullet may have been lodged too deeply to be detected by the crude apparatus.
